data.Name: Joint Initiative at Lombrum Naval Base in PNG
data.Link: The Joint Initiative at Lombrum Naval Base (PNG) | Defence Activities | Defence
data.Summary: The Lombrum Joint Initiative project will work on redeveloping the major naval base on PNG’s Manus Island. Australian firm Clough was awarded the multi-million dollar contract to lead the works in 2021. America has said it will partner with Australia to develop a naval base at the facility.

data.Name: Construction of the Taurama Military Hospital and Primary School
data.Link: Papua New Guinea supports ‘One China’ Policy. – DICT I PNG
data.Summary: The Chinese-funded construction of a new military hospital in Taurama was announced by PNG’s Chief of Defence in 2022, and follows a $500k investment by Beijing in 2007 to redevelop existing medical facilities at Taurama Barracks. The construction is expected to cost more than $AUD13m. In February 2024, PNG and China officials met to finalise plans and designs for the project, according to local reports.

data.Name: Reconstruction of police barracks within the National Capital District
data.Link: Papua New Guinea supports ‘One China’ Policy. – DICT I PNG
data.Summary: PNG’s foreign minister Justin Tkatchenko and his Chinese counterpart led discussions around the reconstruction of police barracks within PNG’s capital district during meetings in 2023. This work is yet to commence, according to a RPNGC spokesperson.

data.Name: Australia – Papua New Guinea Bilateral Security Agreement
data.Link:
Australia – Papua New Guinea Bilateral Security Agreement | Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (dfat.gov.au)

Joint Leaders Statement on the Australia–Papua New Guinea Bilateral Security Agreement | Prime Minister of Australia (pm.gov.au)
data.Summary: The Agreement, signed by Prime Ministers Anthony Albanese and James Marape in 2023, includes provisions for Australia to help support PNG’s police force through training and a $200m investment “in support of Papua New Guinea’s national security priorities”, the Australian government announced. Australia would also allocate new funds to help establish a Port Moresby-based police recruit and investigations training centre.

data.Name: China - PNG Security Cooperation
data.Link: Papua New Guinea in talks with China on security cooperation, foreign minister says | Papua New Guinea | The Guardian
data.Summary: PNG’s Foreign Minister Justin Tkatchenko revealed that his government was in “the early stages of negotiation” around an offer by China to assist with internal policing and security. Following public concern, the Minister walked-back his statement, saying it “is not going to be the end of the world if we do not come to an understanding or agreement with China”.

data.Name: New Zealand - PNG Statement of Partnership
data.Link: PNG NZ Statement of Partnership - 2 July - Final Version (beehive.govt.nz)
data.Summary: The 2021-2024 Partnership commits PNG and NZ to “strengthening [their] respective national security strategies”, while also referencing “non-traditional security challenges” including food security, cybersecurity, and climate security.

data.Name: Australia and Papua New Guinea (PNG) - Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on Aviation
data.Link: Boosting Papua New Guinea's aviation capability | Defence
data.Summary: The agreement facilitated the delivery of two PAC-750XL aircrafts to PNG’s Defence Force and will help strengthen PNG’s air force capabilities.

data.Name: United States and Papua New Guinea (PNG) Defense Cooperation Agreement
data.Link: Agreement between the United States of America and Papua New Guinea
data.Summary: The pact, signed in 2023, would provide $45m to help improve security cooperation and help PNG mitigate the effects of climate change, tackle transnational crime and improve public health. Its signing was controversial, with students in PNG leading protests against the deal. It replaces the SOFA previously in place between the two countries.

data.Name: United Kingdom and Papua New Guinea: Status of Armed Force Agreement (SOFA) Memorandum of Understanding, April 2023
data.Link: PNG signs Security Agreement with United Kingdom. – DICT I PNG
data.Summary: The 2023 SOFA agreement is aimed at “strengthening security and maintaining bilateral relations” between the UK and PNG.

data.Name: AFP - RPNGC Partnership
data.Link: Our work in Papua New Guinea | Australian Federal Police (afp.gov.au)
data.Summary: Provides training and operational support to PNG’s police force. In 2023, the program supported the training of 98 police prosecutors from PNG.

data.Name: Papua New Guinea and Solomon Islands Police Cooperation Agreement,
data.Link: Solomon Islands & Papua New Guinea sign Police Cooperation Agreement – My SIG Services Portal (solomons.gov.sb)
data.Summary: Establishes the deployment of PNG personnel to Solomon Islands for peacekeeping, law enforcement or relief operations.

data.Name: New Zealand Bougainville Community Policing Programme
data.Link: Bougainville Community Policing Programme: Evaluation Report
data.Summary: The Programme deployed several personnel from NZ Police to assist with community policing, and officially ran from 2014 - 2019. The programme is now in transition, through mentoring and coaching Bougainville police leadership.

data.Name: Fiji-Australia Vuvale Partnership
data.Link: Fiji-Australia Vuvale Partnership - signed (dfat.gov.au)
data.Summary: Outlines cooperations between Australian and Fijian defence, security and police forces, including training and joint operational activities.

data.Name: Maritime Essential Services Centre construction
data.Link: Maritime Essential Services Centre (Fiji) | Business & Industry | Defence
data.Summary: The multi-million dollar Centre will house Fiji’s Navy Headquarters, Suva Radio Coastal Station, Fiji’s Maritime Surveillance Coordination Centre, and Fiji’s Hydrographic Office.

data.Name: Blackrock Peacekeeping and Humanitarian Assistance & Disaster Relief Camp
data.Link: Blackrock Peacekeeping and Humanitarian Assistance & Disaster Relief Camp (Fiji) | Business & Industry | Defence
data.Summary: The Camp was opened in 2022, in partnership between the Republic of Fiji Military Forces and the Australian Defence Force. It will help deliver security training to Fijian and regional personnel.

data.Name: Status of Forces Agreement between Fiji and Australia (SOFA)
data.Link: Status of Forces Agreement between Fiji and Australia | Defence Ministers
data.Summary: The 2022 agreement aims to increase defense cooperation, covering issues including immigration and customs, arrangements for visiting forces’ civil and criminal jurisdictions and their ability to wear uniforms while in the other country.

data.Name: Status of Forces Agreement between Fiji and New Zealand (SOFA)
data.Link:
New Zealand and Fiji strengthen defence relationship | Beehive.govt.nz

New Zealand and Fiji strike defence deal amid rising Pacific tensions | Pacific islands | The Guardian
data.Summary: The deal aims to strengthen military training and maritime security, and sets a legal framework for military cooperation between the two countries in each other’s territories. The agreement also covers humanitarian assistance between New Zealand and Fiji.

data.Name: U.S. Defense Attaché Office (USDAO) Suva
data.Link: Defense Attaché - U.S. Embassy in Fiji, Kiribati, Nauru, Tonga, and Tuvalu (usembassy.gov)
data.Summary: The Attaché coordinates defence engagement and security cooperation activities for several Pacific countries, including training, the provision of equipment, humanitarian assistance and coordinating aircraft landings.

data.Name: Nevada National Guard’s State Partnership Program
data.Link: Nevada Guard Welcomes Soldiers from Partners Fiji, Tonga > National Guard > Article View
data.Summary: The partnership program focusses on security cooperation and training. In 2024, soldiers from Fiji and Tonga were invited to compete in a Best Warrior Competition in Las Vegas, organised by the Nevada National Guard.

data.Name: The Defense, International Military Education and Training (IMET) Agreement and Arms
data.Link:
Agreement between the e Governmnet of the United States of America and the Government of the Republic of Fiji regarding the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961

Fiji Government - US AND FIJI SEAL AGREEMENT ON DEFENCE AND SECURITY
data.Summary: The US-Fiji agreement aims to enhance defence and security engagements between the two countries, and builds on an existing 1986 agreement. It also allows Fiji to send officers and senior personnel to professional military education and leadership development courses in the United States.

data.Name: China and Fiji Memorandum of Understanding on Policing
data.Link: Fiji to stick with China police deal after review, home affairs minister says | Fiji | The Guardian
data.Summary: Under the deal, Fijian officers have been trained in China while Chinese police have been embedded in the Fijian force. Beijing has also provided hi-tech equipment including surveillance gear and drones.

data.Name: New Zealand - Fiji police partnership
data.Link:
Police partnership programme with Fiji launched | Beehive.govt.nz

Fiji Police Force
data.Summary: The deal, launched in 2020, focuses on combating transnational organised crime and enhancing investigative skills of Fiji’s police and investigative forces.

data.Name: US - Fiji police training
data.Link: U.S. Trains Fijian and Vanuatuan Military and Police on Counter Drug Training - U.S. Embassy in Fiji, Kiribati, Nauru, Tonga, and Tuvalu (usembassy.gov)
data.Summary: In 2022, US instructors trained 159 Fijian and Vanuatuan Military and Police forces on counter drug operations in Suva and Nadi in Fiji. Last year, the United States further committed to expanding its police training with Fiji’s police force.

data.Name: China - Solomon Islands Security Deal
data.Link: The deal that shocked the world: inside the China-Solomons security pact | Solomon Islands | The Guardian
data.Summary: The secretive agreement was signed in 2022, though details of its content were not immediately made public. Its signing sparked concerns that Chinese military forces could be stationed in the country. However, Solomon Islands’ Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare rejected this suggestion.

data.Name: Australia - Solomon Islands Bilateral Security Treaty
data.Link: Bilateral Security Treaty | Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (dfat.gov.au)
data.Summary: The treaty allows the rapid deployment of Australian police, defence and associated civilian personnel to Solomon Islands. It has been activated to support deployments during the 2021 civil unrest, 2023 Pacific Games and 2024 elections.

data.Name: NZ Defence deployments (election, Pacific games, riots, etc)
data.Link:
Solomon Islands | Ministry of Defence Website

NZ to provide support for Solomon Islands election | Beehive.govt.nz
data.Summary: Four New Zealand personnel will be stationed in Solomon Islands until at least June, 2024, as part of the Solomon Islands International Assistance Force. The NZ Defence Force also sent a team and two NH90 helicopters to provide logistics support for the 2024 election.

data.Name: China - Solomon Islands Policing Pact
data.Link: Solomon Islands signs controversial policing pact with China | Solomon Islands | The Guardian
data.Summary: The deal on police cooperation was signed with China as part of an upgrade of their relations to a “comprehensive strategic partnership”.

data.Name: Royal Solomon Islands Police Force - AFP Policing Partnership Program (RAPPP)
data.Link: Our work in the Solomons | Australian Federal Police (afp.gov.au)
data.Summary: As part of the partnership, the AFP provides technical and operational assistance to support RSIPF with emerging crime and security issues.

data.Name: Papua New Guinea and Solomon Islands Police Cooperation Agreement,
data.Link: Solomon Islands & Papua New Guinea sign Police Cooperation Agreement – My SIG Services Portal (solomons.gov.sb)
data.Summary: Establishes the deployment of PNG personnel to Solomon Islands for peacekeeping, law enforcement or relief operations.

data.Name: Australia - Vanuatu bilateral security agreement
data.Link: Australia Vanuatu Bilateral Security Agreement (dfat.gov.au)
data.Summary: The agreement, which is yet to be ratified by Vanuatu’s parliament, covers various security arrangements, including mutual policing, convening a “security dialogue”, and creating ways to safely share and store classified information.

data.Name: Vanuatu Police and Justice precinct
data.Link: AFP and Vanuatu Police unveil new police and justice precinct | Australian Federal Police
data.Summary: Opened in 2023, the state-of-the-art precinct was built in collaboration with Vanuatu, Australian and UK governments.

data.Name: Vanuatu Australia Policing and Justice Program
data.Link:
AFP and Vanuatu Police Force improving reach and coverage of police in Vanuatu | Australian Federal Police

Vanuatu Australia Policing and Justice Program – P2 Infrastructure
data.Summary: The Vanuatu Australia Policing and Justice Program began in 2017, and has delivered several infrastructure, security and policing projects. In 2023, as part of the Program, Australia’s police force donated Toyota LandCruisers, quad bikes, IT equipment and uniforms to the Vanuatu Police Force.

data.Name: Chinese police equipment and expert deployment
data.Link:
Chinese police experts arrive in Vanuatu amid political crisis | Reuters

Second Batch of Police Supplies from 🇨🇳China Handed Over to 🇻🇺Vanuatu
data.Summary: In 2023, China’s embassy announced a “new era in China-Vanuatu police cooperation” when Beijing sent a team of police experts and supplies amid a political crisis in Vanuatu. A few months later, China sent a second batch of equipment, including electronic forensic equipment, a 16-seater bus and other training gear.

data.Name: Pacific Island Prevention Programme (PIPP)
data.Link: Prevention in the Pacific | New Zealand Police
data.Summary: The four-year program launched by New Zealand in 2018 aims to develop a prevention-centred operating model for policing to police in the Cook Islands, Kiribati, Niue, Samoa, Tokelau, Tuvalu and Vanuatu.

data.Name: Cook Barracks and Tiroas Barracks Redevelopment in Vanuatu
data.Link: Cook Barracks and Tiroas Barracks Redevelopment (Vanuatu) | Business & Industry | Defence
data.Summary: The Cook Barracks and Tiroas Barracks were handed over to the Vanuatu government in 2023 and 2024 respectively following their redevelopment by Australia. They included construction of new medical centres and armouries in barracks at two of Vanuatu’s most populous islands.

data.Name: The Australia-Samoa Bilateral Partnership Arrangement
data.Link: The Australia-Samoa Bilateral Partnership Arrangement | Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (dfat.gov.au)
data.Summary: The wide-ranging agreement, signed in 2023, includes a commitment to greater security cooperation, including training, regular security discussions, information sharing and a recognition of the challenges posed by cybersecurity.

data.Name: Samoa and New Zealand Partnership of Cooperation
data.Link: Statement-of-Partnership-2024-2028.pdf (mfat.govt.nz)
data.Summary: The partnership, signed in 2024 for a 5-year period, includes security as part of its wide-ranging aims. The partnership aims to strengthen cooperation between the countries on police and law enforcement, law and justice, maritime security, humanitarian assistance, cybersecurity, health security, and border security.

data.Name: Samoa-China Bilateral Agreement
data.Link: Samoa signs China bilateral agreement during Pacific push by Beijing | Pacific islands | The Guardian
data.Summary: Details of the 2022 deal are unclear, though the Samoan government said “climate change, the pandemic and peace and security” were discussed when the Samoan prime minister, Fiame Naomi Mata’afa, met Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi before its signing. Since its signing, a Chinese-funded police academy centre was unveiled in capital Apia, and Samoan police travelled to China to take part in peacekeeping capacity training.

data.Name: Australia-Samoa Police Partnership
data.Link: Subsidiary Arrangement between the Government of Australia and the Government of Samoa
data.Summary: Beginning in 2017, and extended for another 4 years in 2021, the Partnership has supported a wide-range of policing initiatives, including CCTV camera installation in capital Apia, motorbike donations, drone training, and the development of a Family Violence Prevention Policy.

data.Name: Pacific Island Prevention Programme (PIPP)
data.Link: Prevention in the Pacific | New Zealand Police
data.Summary: The four-year program launched by New Zealand in 2018 aims to develop a prevention-centred operating model for policing to police in the Cook Islands, Kiribati, Niue, Samoa, Tokelau, Tuvalu and Vanuatu.

data.Name: Tonga-Australia Policing Partnership (TAPP)
data.Link: AFP Bolsters Pacific Security with Samoa Police Training in Tonga | Mirage News
data.Summary: Like its Samoan counterpart, the TAPP is a capability-building program that has supported a range of initiatives, including the purchase of new police uniforms, police training and refurbishment of Tonga’s police facilities. Australia has also delivered some training in conjunction with Samoa’s police force. The bilateral agreement replaced a trilateral agreement between Tonga, Australia and New Zealand, which ended in 2020.

data.Name: Chinese police support
data.Link: People’s Republic of China’s Police and Security visited Tonga – Ko e 'Ofisi 'o e 'Eiki Palemia 'o Tonga (pmo.gov.to)
data.Summary: Ahead of Tonga’s hosting of the Pacific Islands Forum in August 2024, a police and security team from China visited Tonga. The meeting included an offer for Chinese police to assist in securing the Forum meeting, and discussions around the donation of police equipment.

data.Name: Tonga New Zealand Statement of Partnership
data.Link: People’s Republic of China’s Police and Security visited Tonga – Ko e 'Ofisi 'o e 'Eiki Palemia 'o Tonga (pmo.gov.to)
data.Summary: Tonga and New Zealand Prime Ministers met in 2024 to discuss the signing of a new Statement of Partnership after the former deal expired in 2023. It’s expected the partnership will focus on security elements, alongside other priorities.

data.Name: Tonga New Zealand Policing Programme (TNZPP)
data.Link: pmo.gov.to/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/Tonga-Police-Corporate-Plan-and-Budget-2022-23-KPI-update-Jul-22-1.pdf
data.Summary: The Programme has supported training and leadership development of the Tonga Police Force. New Zealand police personnel have also been stationed in Tonga as part of the scheme.
